speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, everyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I remain squarely focused on our dual mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since early last year, the FOMC has significantly tightened the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve raised our policy interest rate by 5¼ percentage points and have continued to reduce our securities holdings at a brisk pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve covered a lot of ground, and the full effects of our tightening have yet to be felt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, we decided to leave our policy interest rate unchanged and to continue to reduce our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, we’re in a position to proceed carefully in determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our decisions will be based on our ongoing assessments of the incoming data and the evolving outlook and risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will have more to say about monetary policy after briefly reviewing economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent indicators suggest that economic activity has been expanding at a solid pace, and, so far this year, growth in real GDP has come in above expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent readings on consumer spending have been particularly robust.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Activity in the housing sector has picked up somewhat, though it remains well below levels of a year ago, largely reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Higher interest rates also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In our Summary of Economic Projections, or SEP, Committee participants revised up their assessments September 20, 2023 of real GDP growth, with the median for this year now at 2.1 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participants expect growth Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL to cool, with the median projection falling to 1.5 percent next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market remains tight, but supply and demand conditions continue to come into better balance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the past three months, payroll job gains averaged 150,000 jobs per month, a strong pace that is nevertheless well below that seen earlier in the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate ticked up in August but remains low at 3.8 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor force participation rate has moved up since late last year, particularly for individuals aged 25 to 54 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nominal wage growth has shown some signs of easing, and job vacancies have declined so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although the jobs-to-workers gap has narrowed, labor demand still exceeds the supply of available workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: FOMC participants expect the rebalancing in the labor market to continue, easing upward pressures on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median unemployment rate projection in the SEP rises from 3.8 percent at the end of this year to 4.1 percent over the next two years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Based on the consumer price index, or CPI, and other data, we estimate that total PCE prices rose 3.4 percent over the 12 months ending in August and that, excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 3.9 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year, and longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nevertheless, the progress—process of getting inflation sustainably down to 2 percent has a long way to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection in the SEP for total PCE inflation is 3.3 percent this year, falls to 2.5 percent next year, and reaches 2 percent in 2026.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware September 20, 2023 that high inflation imposes significant hardship, as it erodes purchasing power, especially for Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks that high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we’re strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I noted earlier, since early last year, we have raised our policy rate by 5¼ percentage points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see the current stance of monetary policy as restrictive, putting downward pressure on economic activity, hiring, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, the economy is facing headwinds from tighter credit conditions for households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In light of how far we have come in tightening policy, the Committee decided at today’s meeting to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 5¼ to 5½ percent and to continue the process of significantly reducing our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to achieving and sustaining a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to our 2 percent goal over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In our SEP, FOMC participants wrote down their individual assessments of an appropriate path for the federal funds rate, based on what each participant judges to be the most likely—sorry—the most likely scenario going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If the economy evolves as projected, the median participant projects that the appropriate level of the federal funds rate will be 5.6 percent at the end of this year, 5.1 percent at the end of 2024, and 3.9 percent at the end of 2025.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Compared with our June Summary of Economic Projections, the median projection is unrevised for the end of this year but has moved up by ½ percentage point at the end of the next two years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These projections, of course, are not a Committee decision or plan; if the economy does not evolve as projected, the path of policy will adjust as appropriate to foster our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting, based on the totality of the September 20, 2023 incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation, as well Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL as the balance of risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Given how far we have come, we are in a position to proceed carefully as we assess the incoming data and the evolving outlook and risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Real interest rates now are well above mainstream estimates of the neutral policy rate, but we are mindful of the inherent uncertainties in precisely gauging the stance of policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re prepared to raise rates further if appropriate, and we intend to hold policy at a restrictive level until we’re confident that inflation is moving down sustainably toward our objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate to return inflation to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keeping longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below-trend growth and some softening of labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I would characterize the, the situation a little bit differently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we decided to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate where it is—at 5¼ to 5½ percent—while continuing to reduce our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we say we’re committed to achieving and sustaining a stance of monetary policy that’s sufficiently restrictive to bring down inflation to 2 percent over time—we said that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the fact that we decided to maintain the policy rate at this meeting doesn’t mean that we’ve decided that we have or have not at this time reached that—that stance of monetary policy that we’re seeking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you looked at the SEP, as you—as you obviously will have done, you will see that a majority of participants believe that it is more likely than not that we will—that it will be appropriate for us to raise rates one more time in the two remaining meetings this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Others believe that we have already reached that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s, it’s something where we’re—by, by—we’re not making a decision by, by deciding to—about that question by deciding to just maintain the rate and await further data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not saying—yeah, no, no—clearly, we’re just—what we decided to do is maintain a policy rate and await further data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to see convincing evidence, really, that we have reached the appropriate level, and then, you know, we’re—we’ve—we’ve seen progress, and, and we welcome that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we need to see more progress before we’ll be willing to—to reach that conclusion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say it this way: First of all, interest rates—real interest rates are, are positive now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re meaningfully positive, and that’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We need policy to be restrictive so that we can get inflation down to target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we need—we’re going to need that to remain to be the case for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think, you know—remember that the—of course, the SEP is not a plan that is negotiated or discussed, really, as a plan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a cumulation, really, and what you see are the medians.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a cumulation of individual forecasts from 19 people, and then what you’re seeing are the medians.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t want to, you know, bestow upon it the idea that, that it’s really a plan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what it reflects, though, is that economic activity’s been stronger than we expected—stronger than I think everyone expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and so what you’re—what you’re seeing is, this is what people believe, as of now, will be appropriate to achieve what we’re looking to achieve, which is progress toward our—toward our inflation goal, as you see in the SEP. MICHELLE SMITH.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let’s go to Rachel.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the proposal at the meeting was to—was to maintain our current policy stance, and, and I think there was obviously unanimous support for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But this, of course, is an SEP meeting, and so people write down what they think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’ve got—you have some—you saw, I think—seven wrote down no hike at this—at this meeting—or between September 20, 2023 now and the end of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think 12 wrote down another single hike in one of the next Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL two meetings that we have between the end of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it wasn’t like we were arguing over that—people just stating their positions—and, really, what, what people are saying is, “Let’s see how the data come in.” You know, we, we want to see—you know what we want to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to see, you know—the, the labor market report that we received, the last one that we received, was a good example of what we do—of what we do want to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was a combination of, of, you know, of—across a broad range of indicators, continuing rebalancing of the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those are the two things—so those are our two mandate variables, and, and that’s, that’s the progress that we want to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think people—they want to be convinced, you know—they want to be careful to—not to jump to a conclusion, really, one way or the other—but just be convinced that the data, you know, support that conclusion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why, given how far we’ve come and how quickly we’ve come, we’re actually in a position to be able to proceed carefully as we assess the incoming data and the evolving outlooks and risks and make these decisions meeting by meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, you, you can make the argument that one hike one way or the other won’t matter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, for us, we’re, we’re trying—obviously, as a group, it’s a pretty tight cluster of, of where we think that, that policy stance might be, but we’re always September 20, 2023 going to be learning from data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve learned all through the course of the last year Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL that, actually, we needed to go further than we had thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you go back a year—and what we thought, what we wrote down—it’s actually gotten higher and higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we don’t really know until—and that’s why, again, we—we’re in a position to proceed carefully at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A year ago, we proceeded pretty quickly to get rates up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now—now we’re fairly close, we think, to where we need to get.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s just a question of reaching the right stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t attribute huge importance to one hike in, in macroeconomic terms.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, you know, we need—we need to get to a place where we’re confident that we have a stance that will bring inflation down to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we need to get to, and we’ve been—you know, we’ve been moving toward it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we’ve gotten closer to it, we’ve slowed the pace at which we’ve moved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that was appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now that we’re getting closer, we, we—again, we have the ability to proceed carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I guess I would point more to—rather than pointing to a sense of inflation having become more persistent, I wouldn’t think—that’s not—we’ve, we’ve seen September 20, 2023 inflation be more persistent over the course of the past year, but I wouldn’t say that’s something Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL that’s appeared in the recent data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s more about stronger economic activity, I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if, if I had to attribute one thing—again, we’re, we’re picking medians here and trying to attribute one explanation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think, broadly, stronger economic activity means, means rates—we have to do more with rates, and that’s what—that’s what that meaning is, is telling you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of, of what the neutral rate can be—you know, we—we know it by its works.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We only know it by its works, really.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can’t—we can’t—you know, the, the models and, and—that we use, you—ultimately, you only know when you get there and by, by the way the economy reacts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, that’s another reason why we’re—why we’re moving carefully now, because, you know, there are lags here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it, it may—it may, of course, be that the—that the neutral rate has risen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You do see people—you don’t see the median moving—but you do see people raising their estimates of, of the neutral rate, and it’s certainly plausible that the neutral rate is higher than, than the longer-run rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Remember—what we write down in the SEP is the longer-run rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is certainly possible that, you know, that the—that the neutral rate at this moment is higher than that, and that—that’s part of the explanation for why the economy has been more resilient than, than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is a—it is a good thing that we, we’ve seen now meaningful rebalancing in the labor market without an increase in unemployment, and that’s, that’s because we’re seeing that rebalancing in other places—in, for example, job openings and in the jobs–worker gap.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re also seeing supply-side things—so, so that’s happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, though, we still—I still think, and I think, broadly, people still think, that there will have to be some softening in the labor market that can come through more supply, as we’ve seen as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Also, remember, the natural rate, we think, is, is coming down, which is a supply-side thing, so that the, the gap between any given unemployment rate that’s lower than that and the natural rate comes down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a way for supply—that’s a way for the labor market to achieve a better balance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So all of those things are happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right—in, in the median forecast, we don’t see a big increase in unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do see an increase, and—but that’s—that really is just “playing forward” the trends that we’ve been seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is not guaranteed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There, there may come a time when unemployment goes up more than that, but that’s, that’s really what we’ve been seeing is, progress without higher unemployment for now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, no—I would not do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve always thought that the soft landing was, was a plausible outcome—that there was a path, really, to, to a soft landing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve thought that, and I’ve said that since we lifted off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s also possible that, that the path has narrowed, and it’s widened, apparently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ultimately, September 20, 2023 it—this may be decided by factors that are outside our control at the end of the day.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I do Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL think it’s—I do think it’s possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know—I also think, you know, this is why we’re in a position to, to move carefully again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That—we, we will restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we know that we have to do that, and we know the public depends on us doing that, and we know that we have to do it so that we can achieve the kind of labor market that we all want to achieve, which is an extended period—sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The fact that we’ve come this far lets us really proceed carefully, as I keep saying.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think, you know, that’s, that’s the end we’re trying to achieve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t want to handicap the likelihood of it, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not up to me to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, yes—we, we understand that it’s a real rate that will matter and that needs to be sufficiently restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, I would say, you know—you know “sufficiently restrictive” only when you see it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You—it’s not something you can arrive at with confidence in a model or, or in various estimates, you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re, we’re seeing, you know, through a combination of the, you know, the unwinding of the pandemic-related demand and supply distortions and monetary policy’s work in suppressing September 20, 2023 demand or, or, you know, alleviating very high demand—the combination of those two things is Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL actually working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re seeing, you know, inflation coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s principally now in goods—also in housing services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You begin to see effects of it in nonhousing services as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think—we think that that is working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I think, you know—as we’ve said, we, we want to reach that—we want to reach something that we’re confident gets us to that level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s a whole other set of questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For now, the question is trying to find that level where we think we can stay there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we haven’t—we haven’t gotten to a point of confidence about that yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s what we’re—that’s, that’s the stage we’re at, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The decision that we make at, you know, at each meeting and, certainly, at the—at the last two meetings this year—it’s going to depend on the totality of all the data: so, the inflation data, the labor market data, the growth data, the, the balance of risks, and the other events that are happening out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll make—we take all of that into account, so I can’t really answer a hypothetical about one piece of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll—it’ll be trying to reach a September 20, 2023 judgment over whether we should move forward with another rate hike overall and whether that Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL would increase our confidence that, that, yes, this is an appropriate move, and it will help, help us be more confident that we’ve gotten to the level that we need to get to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When—so when I answer these questions about hypotheticals about, about cutting, I’m never intending to send a signal about timing; I’m just answering them as, as the question is expressed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, so please—I, I wouldn’t want to be taken that way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah, so we’re—as we go into next year, that’s the question we’ll be asking is—you know, taking into account lags and, and everything else we know about the economy and everything we know about monetary policy, the, the time will come at some point, and I’m not saying when, that it’s—that it’s appropriate to cut.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Part of that may be that real rates are rising because inflation is coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Part of it just may be that—it’ll be all the factors that we see in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that time will certainly come at some point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 20, 2023 And you—what you see is us writing down, you know, a year ahead, estimates of what that Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, there’s—you know, there’s so much uncertainty around that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In, in—when we—in the moment, we’ll do what we think makes sense.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No one will look back at this and say, “Hey, we made a plan.” It’s not like that at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—this is—these are estimates made a year in advance that are highly uncertain, and that’s how it is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So on, on your first question—I mean, we’re looking at GDP very, very carefully to try to understand really what’s the direction of it—what’s, what’s driving it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s, it’s a lot of consumer spending, you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been—the consumer’s been very robust in its—in spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is, you know, that’s how we’re looking at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry, your second question was— NEIL IRWIN.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Maximum employment and price stability are the mandates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s going to be the question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not—it’s not a question about GDP on its own.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, you—you know, you’re expecting to see the—this improvement, you know—continued rebalancing in the labor market and inflation moving back down to 2 percent September 20, 2023 in a sustainable way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to have confidence in that, and, you know, we’d be—we’d be Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL looking at GDP just, just to the extent that it threatens one or both of those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there is a—there is a long list, and you hit some of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it—you know, it’s, it’s the strike, it’s government shutdown, resumption of student loan payments, higher long-term rates, oil price shock.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, you could—there are a lot of things that you can—you can look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know—so, what we try to do is assess all of them and, and handicap all of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, ultimately, though, there’s so much uncertainty around, around these things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, to, to start with the strike—first of all, we absolutely don’t comment on the strike, as we have no view on the strike one way or the other.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we, we do have to make an assessment of its economic effects to do our jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, the, the thing about it is—so uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will depend.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic effects—it could affect—you’ve looked—we’ve looked back at history—it could affect economic output, hiring, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s really going to depend on how broad it is and how long it’s sustained for.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—and then it also depends on how quickly production can make up for, for lost production.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So none of those things are known right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s very, very hard to know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you just have to leave that uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and we’ll be learning, I think, over the course of the next intermeeting period, much more about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the same is true for the others.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we—I don’t know if you September 20, 2023 mentioned shutdown; I think of all of these as being on the list.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t comment on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL hasn’t traditionally had much of a macroeconomic effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, energy prices being higher—that’s—that is a significant thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—energy prices being up can affect spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It can affect the consumer over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A sustained period of higher—of higher energy prices can affect consumer expectations about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We tend to look through short-term volatility and look at—look at core inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to—we have to take those macroeconomic effects into account as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are—those are some of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not sure if I hit them all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But—I mean, ultimately, you know, you’re, you’re coming into this with an economy that appears to have significant momentum.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s what we start with.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—but we do have this collection of risks that you mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To begin: A soft landing is a primary objective, and I did not say otherwise.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, that’s, that’s what we’ve been trying to achieve for all this time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The, the real point, though, is—the, the worst thing we can do is to fail to restore price stability, because the record is clear on that: If you, you don’t restore price stability, inflation comes back, and you go through—you can have a long period where the economy’s just very uncertain, and it will affect growth; it will affect all kinds of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It can be a miserable period to have inflation constantly coming back and the Fed coming in and having to tighten again and again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the best thing we can do for everyone, we believe, is to restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think now, today, we actually—you know, we, we have the ability to be careful at this point and move carefully, and that’s what we’re planning to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we fully appreciate that—you know, the benefits of being able to continue what we see already, which is rebalancing in the labor market and inflation coming down without seeing, you know, an important, large increase in unemployment, which has been typical of other tightening cycles.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So— MICHELLE SMITH.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let’s go to Chris.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if I—if I understood your question, it’s—I would say it this way: I think we knew from the time—from before when we lifted off, but certainly by the time we lift—we knew that bringing inflation back down was going to take, as I call it, the unwinding of these distortions to both supply and demand that happened because of the pandemic and the response.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that unwinding was going to be important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, monetary policy was going to help.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was going to help supply side heal by, by cooling demand off and, just in general, September 20, 2023 better aligning supply with demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those two forces were always going to be important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL think it’s very hard to pull them apart.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They work together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I do think both of them are at work now, and I think they’re at work in a way that shows you the progress that we—that we are seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, forecasts are highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Forecasting is very difficult.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Forecasters are a humble lot with much to be humble about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Stronger than expected—and that’s required higher rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Unemployment, you know—you also see that the, the ultimate unemployment rate is not as high, but that—that’s really because of what we’ve been seeing in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen more and more progress in the labor market without seeing significantly higher unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re continuing that trend.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of inflation, you, you are seeing—the last three readings are, are very good readings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s only three readings, you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—we’re well aware that we need to see more than three readings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But if you look at June, July, and August, you’re looking at, you know, really significant declines in core inflation, largely in the goods sector—also to some extent in housing services and just a little in nonhousing services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are the three buckets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Headline inflation, of course, has come way September 20, 2023 down, largely due to lower energy prices, some of which is now reversing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think—people Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL should know that, that economic forecasting is very difficult, and these are highly uncertain forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But these are—these are our forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, they’re, they’re—we have very high-quality people working on these forecasts, and I think they stand up well against other forecasters.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But just the nature of the business is, the economy is very difficult to forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I, I think we have come very far very fast in, in the, the rate increases that we’ve made.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it was important at the beginning that we move quickly, and we did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and I think as we get closer to the rate that we think—the stance of monetary policy that we think is appropriate to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time, you know, the risks become more two sided, and the risk of overtightening and the risk of, of undertightening becomes more equal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think the, the natural, commonsense thing to do is, as you approach that, you move a little more slowly as you get closer to it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, that’s what we’re doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re taking advantage of the fact that we have moved quickly to move a little more carefully now as we—as we sort of find our way to, to the right level of restriction that we need to get inflation back down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry—yeah, I missed the first question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Base factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can look at just monthly readings and see what the increase was from the prior month.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re right—when you go back 3, 6, and 12 months, you get base factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we can—we can adjust for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of not getting data—you know, again, we don’t—we don’t comment on government shutdowns.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It—it’s possible—if, if there is a government shutdown and it lasts through the, the next meeting, then it’s possible we wouldn’t—we wouldn’t be getting some of the data that we would ordinarily get, and we—you know, we would just have to deal with that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s hard for me to say in advance how that would affect that meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would depend on all kinds of factors that I don’t know about now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s certainly a reality that, that that’s a possibility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that’s what we’re looking at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I think—I think what we’re really looking at is, there’s a tendency to look at, you know, shorter and shorter maturities, but they’re incredibly volatile, and they can be misleading.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s why we look at 12-month [rates].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 20, 2023 But I think, in this situation—where it looks like we’ve had a bit of a turn in inflation starting in Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL June—we’re also looking at six months, and even three months, but really six months’ inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re looking at it over that period and over longer periods.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That—that’s the right way to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t—we don’t need to be in a hurry to—in, in getting to a conclusion about what to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can let the data evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So— MICHELLE SMITH.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Edward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, energy prices are very important for the consumer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This, this can affect consumer spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It certainly can affect consumer sentiment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, gas prices are one of the big things that, that affects consumer sentiment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It, it really comes down to how persistent—how sustained these energy prices are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The reason why we look at core inflation, which excludes food and energy, is that energy goes up and down like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it doesn’t—energy, energy prices mostly, mostly don’t contain much of a signal about how tight the economy is, and hence don’t tell you much about where inflation’s really going.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, we’re well aware, though, that, that, you know, if energy prices increase and stay high, that’ll have an effect on spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and it may have an effect on, on consumer expectations of inflation—things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s just things we have to monitor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, to, to finish my prior thought, I was saying that’s why we tend to look through energy moves that we—that we can see as, as short-term volatility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, turning to consumer credit, you know—of course, we watch that carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Consumer distress—measures of distress among consumers were at historic lows quite recently, you know, after—during and after the, the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re now moving back up to normal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re, we’re watching that carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, at this point, these, these readings are not at troublingly high levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re, they’re just kind of moving back up to what was the typical [level] in the pre-pandemic era.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, rates have moved up significantly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s always hard to say precisely, but it’s—most, most people do a common decomposition of the increase, and they’ll, they’ll—the view will be, it’s not—it’s not mostly about inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s mostly about other things, you know—either term premium or real yields—and it’s, it’s hard to be precise about this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, everyone’s got models that’ll give you a very precise answer, but they give you different answers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but, essentially, they’re, they’re moving up because—it’s not because of inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s because probably—it’ll probably have September 20, 2023 something to do with stronger growth, I would say—more, more supply of Treasuries.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL know, the common explanations that you hear in the markets kind of make sense.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So on the supply point—of course, supply is very important over time in, in setting house prices and, and, for that matter, rents.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so—and supply is kind of structurally constrained.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But in terms of, of where inflation’s going in the near term, though, as, as you obviously know, a lot of it is, is leases that are running off and then being re-signed or re-leased at a level that’s, that’s not as—it won’t be that much higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A year ago, it would have been much higher than it was a year before; now it may be below or at the same level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So as those leases are rolling over, we’re, we’re seeing what we expect, which is measured housing services inflation coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Your second question was the lock-ins.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I think we look at the—I would look at the lock-in, the, the idea being that people are in, in very low mortgage—very low-rate mortgages, and if—even if they want to move now, they—it would be hard because the new mortgage would be so expensive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s explaining some of the—that’s one of the explanations for what’s happening broadly in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, I, I don’t think it would.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, you know, in, in an emergency like the pandemic or during the Global Financial Crisis, you, you know, the, the—you have to cut rates to the point that—you have to do, do what you can to support the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t—I wouldn’t think that that would be a reason for us not to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not something we’re thinking about at all right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, down the road, I wouldn’t think so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I wouldn’t say it that way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not looking for a decrease in consumer spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s a good thing that the economy’s strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a good thing that the September 20, 2023 economy has been able to hold up under, under the tightening that we’ve done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a good thing Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL that the labor market’s strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The, the only concern—it, it just means this: If the economy comes in stronger than expected, that just means we’ll have to do more in terms of monetary policy to get back to 2 percent—because we will get back to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, that’s always a concern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, concern number one is, is restoring price stability, because in the long run, that’s, that’s something we have to do so that we can have the kind of economy we really want, which is one with sustained period of tight labor market conditions that benefit all, as I—as I’ve said a couple times.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that, that said—of course, you know—we, we also now, given how far we’ve come with our rate hikes and how quickly we’ve come here, we do have the ability to be careful as we move forward because of that consideration.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what—I guess it’s fair—it’s fair to say that the economy has been stronger than many expected, given, given what’s been happening with, with interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many candidate explanations—possibly—a number of them make sense.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One, one is just that household balance sheets and business balance sheets have been stronger than we had understood, and so that, that spending has held up—and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not sure about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The savings rate for consumers has come down a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The question is whether that’s sustainable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That could—it could just mean that the—that the date of effect is, is later.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It could also be that for other reasons, the neutral rate of interest is, is higher for—for various reasons.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It could also just be that policy hasn’t been restrictive enough for long enough.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s—there are many candidate explanations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to, in, in all this uncertainty, make policy, and I, you know, I feel like what we have right now is what’s still a very strong labor market—but that’s coming back into balance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were making progress on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth is strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think by many forecasts—many, many, many forecasts call for growth to, to moderate over the course of the next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s where we are, and, you know, we have to—we have to deal with what comes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so the point I would make there is that we’re trying to get inflation back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The people who are most hurt by inflation are the people who are on a fixed income.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you’re a person who spends all of your income, you don’t really have any meaningful savings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You spend all your income on the basics of life—clothing, food, transportation, heating—the basics—and prices go up by 5, 6, 7 percent, you’re in trouble right away, whereas even, even middle-class people have some savings and some ability to absorb that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it is for those people as much as for anybody that we need to restore price stability, and, and we, we want to do it as quickly as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Obviously, we—we’d like to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d like the current trend to continue, which is that we’re making progress without seeing the kind of increase in unemployment that we’ve seen past—in past things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you’re right, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When we raise rates, people who are, you know, living on credit cards and, and borrowing are going to feel that more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, people with, with lots of savings also have a—have a much lower marginal propensity to consume, and so they’re not going to—it’s not going to affect them as much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I don’t know about the quarterly survey.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s an idea we can—we can take away and think about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of how low and moderate Americans—you know, they’re clearly—were suffering from, from high inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think during the pandemic, the, the government transfers that happened were very meaningful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, if you know the—the surveys that we take showed that—showed that low- and moderate-income people were actually in very, very strong financial condition.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think now it’s a very “hot” labor market, and you’re seeing high [growth in] nominal wages, and you’re starting to see [that growth rates of] real wages are now positive by most—by most measures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I think, overall, households are in good shape.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Surveys are a different thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So surveys are showing dissatisfaction, and I think a lot of that is just, people hate inflation—hate it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, that causes people to say, “The economy’s terrible.” But, at the same time, they’re spending money.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Their behavior is, is not exactly what you would expect from the surveys.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s kind of a, a guess at what the answer might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I, I think there’s a lot of good things happening on household balance sheets—and, certainly, in the labor market and with wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The biggest wage increases having gone to relatively low-wage jobs—and now [with] inflation coming down—you’re seeing [increases in] real wages, which is a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
